DOC.HEAD: Pope Prays for Eastern Europe, Emerging from ``Nightmare'
With AM-World Christmas, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II offered a special prayer for the people of Romania and expressed hope in his traditional Christmas message that the spirit of the holiday will reach across his native Eastern Europe. In his gold robes and miter, the pope emerged at noon on his balcony overlooking sun-dappled St. Peter's Square, where tens of thousands of faithful and tourists listened to the annual ``Urbi et Orbi,'' Latin for ``to the city and to the world.'' ``May the light that came into the world on this blessed day shine in your hearts and in your homes always,'' the pope said in English, his head bowed. ``The world longs for peace,'' John Paul declared, then listed conflicts worldwide: Lebanon, the Holy Land, Central America, Africa and Asia. After his words about Eastern Europe and especially Romania, the pope paused for a few seconds and lifted his head. ``May this old Europe of ours also receive you, O Word Incarnate!'' he said. ``Deep within her she carries the imprint of your gospel from which she has derived her culture, her art, her concept of the inviolable dignity of man.'' ``May this Europe open her doors and her heart to understand and receive the anxieties, the fears and the problems of the nations which seek her help,'' the pope said. ``May she respond with the strength and the generosity of her Christian roots to this very special moment of history ... which the world is now experiencing as if awakened from a nightmare and opened up to a better hope.'' Although he did not name the countries, it was clear the pope was referring to Czechoslovakia, East Germany, Bulgaria, Hungary, and his native Poland, where Communist regimes this year have seen their once-absolute power shaken and diluted. In Romania, a popular revolt ousted the hard-line Communist leader, Nicolae Ceausescu, but thousands of people are believed to have died in fighting between pro- and anti-Ceausescu forces. ``In particular, bless at this hour, O Lord, the noble land of Romania, which is celebrating this Christmas in fear and trembling with sorrow for the many human lives tragically lost and in the joy of having taken once more the path of freedom,'' the pope said. He paused to bring his folded hands to his face as if deep in thought, then looked up after a few seconds and finished his speech. In keeping with his custom, the pope ended his public appearance by saying ``Merry Christmas'' in 53 languages, beginning in Italian and ending in Latin. In his message, the pope also prayed for guidance for negotiators involved in arms control agreements and denounced the ``self-interest'' or ``lack of concern'' that aggravates pollution. He also cited the plight of ethnic and religious minorities and refugees without citing specific nations or groups. The pope did not mention Panama, where ousted dictator Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega has sought refuge at the Vatican Embassy to evade U.S. troops sent in to capture him. More than 200 people have died as a result of the fighting.
